text:
Welcome to How To Cook That i'm Ann Reardon 
and i came across a fascinating plant called a

marshmallow plant now i heard a rumor that the 
roots of these plants used to be used to make

marshmallows so that sent me on a quest to search 
for the original old marshmallow recipe so that we

can test it out i came across this 360 year 
old book of practical physique or medicine

and i have to show you this bit this was not 
about marshmallow but they talk about using

fresh ox dung or cow dung and mixing it with 
sulfur frankincense honey vinegar and the broth

of cabbage to make a cataplasm to put on swellings 
which is pretty gross if we scroll further down on

the same page of this book it has the first recipe 
i could find with marshmallow root in it it says

to take the muculidge of marshmallow root linseed 
fenugreek goose fat the marrow of a leg of veal

flower delucy root chamomile flowers each of 
two ounces merv frankincense oil of chamomile

and wax and they basically mix that all together 
to make an m plaster or a paste that they used

with linen strips when they were putting on 
a plaster it wasn't until 1810 that i found a

written recipe for the famous tablets digi move or 
french lozenges of marshmallow being their grand

remedy for all sorts of coughs let's make some of 
them and see what they're like this is to cleanse

and scrape out the roots of marshmallows freshly 
taken out of the earth the marshmallow plants are

quite tall and they die off in the winter and 
then new plants will spring up from the base

like you can see here for this recipe we're after 
just the roots and these have already been washed

to get all the soil off now i'm just going to cut 
the roots out and separate them off and then it

says to scrape them i'm not quite sure how we 
do that but i'm assuming we scrape it with a

knife and that seems to be working fairly well 
the skin bit is coming off it as with most old

recipes though it is going to take me a while to 
get through all of these and get it all taken off

i assume that you then slice them they've got a 
weird feel to them they feel kind of sticky but

then if you wash your hands it instantly turns 
to slime and feels really slippery and slimy

next it says to boil them in pure water until 
they become quite soft so i'm going to boil them

and leave them boiling until they are soft and 
then it says take them out of their decoction

beat them in a marble mortar until the consistency 
of a fine smooth paste let me just grab all that

marshmallow root out of that goopy liquid that's 
left at the bottom and now for my least favorite

tool in olden days cooking videos the mortar and 
basil let's beat this up i am forever grateful for

food processors they make this job so much easier 
my arm is already tired but what do you think

will that do is it the consistency of a 
fine smooth paste i don't know it smells

of asparagus it kind of stinks next it says to 
place it on top of an inverted sieve and obtain

all the pulp which can be forced through the 
sieve with the assistance of a wooden spoon

this stuff does not want to push through 
a sieve it's gooey it's sticky it's really

thick and this is going to take me a long 
time it is quite possible i didn't do a good

enough job with the mortar and pestle 
and that might be making this harder

i have finally managed to get some of it through 
and i think the rest is going to have to be left

because it makes you just realize how hard they 
worked for everything if we want to throat lozenge

you just go and get one from the shops but i've 
got a blister from trying to push marshmallow

root through a sieve to make them moving on it 
says then boil a pound and a half of loaf sugar

in six or seven ounces of rose water to a good 
solid consistency now old recipes tend to be

pretty sparse on details so do they mean this 
mixture should cook until it's a solid consistency

or until when we drop some in cold water it goes 
solid like you do in candy making i'm assuming the

latter otherwise it would just burn once it's 
hot enough it says whisk it up with a quarter

of a pound of the marshmallow pulp after which 
place it over a gentle heat to dry up the humidity

stirring it all the time until a good paste 
is formed now adding the marshmallow root

and then stirring seems to be making the sugar 
crystallize again into more of a fudgy consistency

i was expecting a smooth lozenge like we get today 
but it's clear it's not going to be like that

then it says to cut it into lozenges with a 
proper tin lozenge cutter now that is a gadget

that i do not have so a knife is going to have 
to suffice the mechanical lozenge cutters weren't

invented yet they were another 40 years later so 
i assume the writer of the book just had a small

lozenge shaped like a mini cookie cutter let's see 
what the family think of these lozenges before we

try another marshmallow root recipe this is more 
worrying than usual only because i know like

old medicines sometimes have weird stuff in them 
it looks kind of like a crouton like i thought it

was going to be like a soft spongy thing and then 
you said it was a lozenge so not not bread give it

a taste and let me know what you think did i eat 
the whole thing you're supposed to suck on them ah
well it's a funny flavor it's very sweet

tastes like sugar infused with banana peel 
flavor not banana but the flavor of banana peel

tastes like a caramel flavored 
leaf it tastes like grass

so i guess that one's not a winner moving 
forward in time 13 years to 1823 and we find

a recipe for pater digumov or marshmallow paste 
it says take a decoction of marshmallow roots

four ounces and water one gallon boil four pints 
and strain now i'm going to chop this marshmallow

root up more finely this time the recipe said 
to boil from one gallon to four pints which is

half the volume so i'm just going to mark here 
where we started and then i can just turn off

the heat every now and then and check where it's 
up to once it gets down to half i'm just going

to pour it through a cheesecloth to strain it now 
thankfully this recipe is using the juice not the

pulp so i don't have to push it through the sieve 
which i'm very glad about then it says add the gum

arabic half a pound and refined sugar two pounds 
now i've bought some gum arabic powder i couldn't

get the gamma rabbit or acacia gum crystals and 
this powder is expensive so this is only one ounce

not half a pound and i've scaled down the rest 
of the recipe so we've got less sugar and a small

amount of the decoction from the marshmallow root 
let's put these two in the pan and then it says

evaporate to an extract then take from the 
fire stir it quickly with the whites of 12

eggs previously beaten to a froth well just as 
well we read ahead because i don't know when it

previously told us to beat these up so i'd better 
beat the egg white first this is of course not 12

egg whites because i'm scaling the recipe down and 
if you want to make these old recipes i'll put all

the details on my website howtocookthat.net and 
a photo of the original recipe for you as well

hand whipping egg whites makes me very grateful 
for electric mixes as i said cooking was very time

consuming back then i'm going to put this 
in fast forward and see how long it takes

two and a half minutes of beating by hand and it 
is ready to go now let's heat up the gum arabic

sugar and marshmallow root decoction and it says 
to evaporate to an extract but i'm not sure what

that means exactly is this an extract i mean 
an extract is a concentrate so i'm going to put

some on a plate to cool and see it's still just 
really liquid and i think i'm going to keep it

boiling until it's thick and set when it's cooled 
all right i've evaporated off lots of the water

and we've got this hot thick liquid and so then 
it says to stir it quickly in with the whites

so i'll tip the rest of that in and whip it 
together and that kind of does look like an

unset marshmallow there were no more directions 
apart from adding a little orange flower water to

flavor it so i'm going to put some corn flour 
onto baking paper and dip it on top just like

i would if i was making a marshmallow now i'm 
only going to put half of this onto the paper

though because the very next recipe in the book 
on the same page which was also for pata digimov

is very similar but it's left out the marshmallow 
root they just had plain water instead

but when it gets to the stage that we're at now 
it says to evaporate over a slow fire stirring it

continually until it will not stick to the fingers 
it should be very light spongy and extremely white

now that sounds more like normal marshmallow to 
me so let's try that method with the other half

stirring continually until it won't stick to the 
fingers it definitely still sticks to my fingers

at the moment it's interesting that this is the 
earliest published recipe that i could find for

marshmallow paste and already it has an option 
with no marshmallow root in it apparently that's

because some people found the marshmallow root 
flavour disagreeable and the gum arabic was just

as effective at relieving coughs i'm not exactly 
sure what i'm supposed to be looking for here

it still sticks to my finger even now but it's 
pretty thick and it's starting to catch on the

bottom so i think i'm just going to call it and 
pull it off the heat today marshmallow isn't even

made using gum arabic we use gelatin now because 
it's much much cheaper if you want to know why

they didn't use gelatin in this recipe 200 years 
ago then you'll have to watch the 200 year old

trifle recipe and you'll get the idea this first 
one is still very foamy i won't be able to slice

that it hasn't set but the second one is set but 
it's still soft it's not hard so let's see how

they taste pate de marshmallow marshmallow patty 
it hasn't sticked so let's just put it on a spoon

you can't really imagine 
putting this in a hot chocolate

it's not bad there's there's still a hint 
of something something there that's not

quite what we would expect from 
marshmallow like there's definitely a um

a plant flavor in there you can definitely gotta 
get a hint of marshmallow in there but it's not

kind of the classic marshmallow flavor that we're 
used to it's like marshmallow mixed with the other

one was caramel mixed with leaf it seems to be a 
trend i hope the next one doesn't taste like bark
just made in a different way okay

you know what's weird it kind of reminds me 
of one of those like water bear creatures

like the microscopic ones it's really gross 
i'm sure it tastes better than one of them

i know something that tastes exactly like this 
but i can't pick it it's a strange flavor it's

a little bit like a nougat that that one 
had much more of the marshmallow texture

but also with it a lot more of that slightly 
off flavor that was in the other ones

i quite like it the mystery ingredient in all 
those recipes is marshmallow root there's a

plant called marshmallow and that's the root 
of it really a plant called marshmallow do they

still use it they don't use it in marshmallows 
anymore but it was in all of those recipes
grass flavoured secret ingredient
that's where the the bark flavor came from

yeah it's definitely that flavor not exactly 
my favorite flavor but interesting times

ancient days we're thanks to my wonderful patrons 
for your ongoing support and encouragement if you

guys liked this video let the algorithm know by 
liking it commenting and sharing here are some

more 200 year old recipe videos for you and if you 
want a modern day marshmallow recipe click on this

one there's one in there make it a great week by 
being kind to others and i'll see you on friday
